gravity_system: Concrete Slab, Steel Frame, Compacted Granular A
other_materials: Aluminized Corrugated Steel Pipe, Granular A, Grout
key_elements: Valve Chamber, Storm Gate, Baseplate Connections, Access Hatch
overall_building_description: The ROCKWOOL Storm Tank Access Hatch project involves a comprehensive integration of structural and environmental engineering principles, focusing on the installation and reinforcement of storm-water management systems. The primary structural components include a 32 MPa concrete slab reinforced with 20M bars at 6 inches on center, both ways top and bottom, ensuring robust load-bearing capacity and durability. The slab is designed with 2 inches of cover at the top and sides and 3 inches at the bottom, optimizing protection against environmental exposure and mechanical wear. The structural framework incorporates W8x18 beams and columns, providing a rigid support system for the storm tank access hatch. The steel frame is further stabilized by HSS 4x4x1/4 braces, enhancing lateral stability and resistance to dynamic loads. The project specifications include detailed installation procedures for the Echelon Environmental storm gate, which is designed to meet AWWA 561-14 standards for strength and leakage. The gate features a 1200mm diameter opening, with a design seating, unseating, and operating head of 5 meters, ensuring efficient water management and control. The manual operator is engineered to function under specified seating and unseating heads with a maximum effort of 80 lbs (356 N), providing reliable operation under varying hydraulic conditions. The installation notes emphasize the necessity for flat, straight, and plumb alignment of the frame assembly, pedestal, wall brace, stem guides, and operator, with shimming and bracing as required to maintain structural integrity. The valve chamber, a critical component of the storm-water management system, is constructed with a chimney cap, access chimney, and concrete rings to adjust the manhole cover to the finished grade. The chamber is anchored with grout, and a ladder is provided with the precast structure to facilitate maintenance access. The valve box is designed to extend to the top of the chamber, with the contractor responsible for parging and sealing around the valve to prevent leakage and ensure compliance with OPSD 401.010 standards. The baseplate connections, detailed in Section A-A, utilize 10"x10"x 3/4" and 16"x12"x 3/4" baseplates, secured with four 3/4" diameter Hilti Kwik Bolts, achieving a minimum embedment of 4 3/4". These connections are critical for transferring loads from the structural frame to the foundation, ensuring stability and safety under operational conditions. The project also includes provisions for site-specific conditions, such as the verification of location and inverts upon excavation, with findings to be reported to SPH Engineering for review and potential design adjustments. This comprehensive approach ensures that the storm tank access hatch is integrated seamlessly into the existing site infrastructure, providing a reliable and efficient solution for storm-water management.
